title: type on 2006 Liberty Silver Dollar
content:
Hi Everyone.

My name is Jesse and I currently work as a CNC Operator in an engraving shop. I have a font dilemma, I am currently working a project for a customer and need to find out what font is used for the 2006 Liberty Silver Dollar. I have searched high and low and am not able to find it. Is this a special font used by the Tresury Dept? I would appreciate any help.

Thank you for your time and assistance.

Jesse
author: jesse zaragoza

comments.content:
The typeface used on a ‘2006 Liberty Silver Dollar’? I am pretty sure that that one would be custom. _( I dont think noone ever used existing, available type for money and currencies. )_ Anyway, If you could post a sample image, someone may actually be able to help you with alternate typeface suggestions.

Dav

<cite>( I dont think noone ever used existing, available type for money and currencies. )</cite>

[Canadian $2](http://web.archive.org/web/20060824164810/http:/www.flickr.com/photo_zoom.gne?id=110670320&size=l) from 2000 used Arial.

I didn’t think any coins used type, either — I figured the lettering was always designed by the sculptor who designed the coin. But you’re right! They used both Univers and Arial. What a disgrace. The Arial doesn’t even curve evenly: the type is too big for the arc it’s sitting on. Shame! They spent about $2 Canadian to design the coin.  
I bet Robt. Bringhurst won’t even carry those coins in his pocket.  
As for the US dollar coin, since it’s a reissue of a design from the 1920’s [assuming I am thinking of the same coin you are] the letters are hand-drawn. Those were the good old days: in 1907, Teddy Roosevelt chose Augustus Saint-Gaudens, a famous American sculptor, to design some coins for the US Mint, as part of a comprehensive redesign of the coultry’s coinage.  
According to Wikipedia, the dollar coin was designed by medalist Anthony de Francisci, a naturalized immigrant from Italy.  
Font Bureau’s Grand Central has some of the flavor of public lettering of the early 20th century…

I’ve got a $2 coin from 1996 and one from 2005 here, and both use Helvetica instead of Arial. I wonder why they switched to Arial in 2000… unless the one in the picture is counterfeit.

- Lex
